results.headline: Christian Rock With a Twist

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Danielson: A Family Movie

results.summary_short: J L Aronson’s documentary is about Daniel Smith, a musician who performs Christian music that is a world away from most of what is heard under that label.

results.headline: After Iraq, Struggling on the Home Front

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Home of the Brave

results.summary_short: The kindest description of “Home of the Brave,” the first Hollywood movie to examine the experience of American soldiers returning from Iraq, might be that it is fueled by noble intentions.

results.headline: Defending the Human Race With Old Spare Parts

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Automatons

results.summary_short: With its retro look, cautionary theme and not-so-special effects, "Automatons" is a shameless ode to ’60s sci-fi and classic television shows.

results.headline: Gay Samurai on a Quest for Experience
results.display_title: Yaji and Kita: The Midnight Pilgrims

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Yaji and Kita: The Midnight Pilgrims

results.summary_short: Like something you might experience after eating very bad meat or very good mushrooms, “Yaji and Kita” is a surreal romp through 19th-century Japan and most of the space-time continuum.

results.headline: On the Slopes With Snowboarders Past and Present

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Snow Blind

results.summary_short: “Snow Blind” calls itself a documentary, but it never stops feeling like the in-house channel on a ski-lodge television.

results.headline: Mischievous Kids Make the Most of a Night at the Airport

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Unaccompanied Minors

results.summary_short: Set on Christmas Eve at a snowed-in Midwestern airport, “Unaccompanied Minors” assembles a squad of familiar adolescent movie types.

results.headline: The Persistence of Intolerance

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ever Again

results.summary_short: This documentary, by an arm of the Simon Wiesenthal Center, seeks to stir up outrage about recent bursts of anti-Semitism in Europe.

results.headline: In the Shadow of His Father, a Son Slowly Comes of Age

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Family Law

results.summary_short: Like father like son: exploratory variations on that old saw are the thematic heart of the Argentine filmmaker Daniel Burman’s “Family Law.”

results.headline: Changing Addresses, Altering Love Lives

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Holiday

results.summary_short: "The Holiday" is a tale of two women, two houses, two love interests — Jude Law pairs with Cameron Diaz, Jack Black gets lucky with Kate Winslet — but it’s also about movie love.

results.headline: The Pros and Cons of Confession

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Forgiveness

results.summary_short: Everyone’s sorry about something in this glum drama about the way repentance can do more damage than the sin that precedes it.

results.headline: Citizens Suffer in a Country Torn by Civil War

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Empire in Africa

results.summary_short: Philippe Diaz’s tumultuous documentary is a noble but failed attempt to explicate the tragedy of Sierra Leone’s 11-year civil war.

results.headline: Diamonds and the Devil, Amid the Anguish of Africa

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blood Diamond

results.summary_short: The makers of this exceptionally foolish thriller starring a most excellent Leonardo DiCaprio want you to know there may be blood on your hands, specifically your wedding finger.

results.headline: Fathers and Sons and Raging Infernos

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Off the Black

results.summary_short: Nick Nolte dives beneath the blubber to bare the weary soul of an automobile junkyard operator pushing 60 who also umpires high-school baseball games.

results.headline: The Passion of the Maya

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Apocalypto

results.summary_short: Mel Gibson's "Apocalypto" is, above all, a muscular and kinetic action movie, a drama of rescue and revenge with very little organic relation to its historical setting.

results.headline: A Solitary Ingmar Bergman on Life, Love and Death, in Documentary Style

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bergman Island

results.summary_short: An extraordinarily revealing documentary portrait of the Swedish director at his home on the desolate Baltic Island of Faro.

results.headline: Yes, Soldiers of France, in All but Name

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Days of Glory

results.summary_short: Algeria’s official Oscar submission for best foreign language film is a damn good war movie.

results.headline: The Trippy Dream Factory of David Lynch

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Inland Empire

results.summary_short: David Lynch's extraordinary, savagely uncompromised new film is as cracked as Mad magazine, though generally more difficult to parse.

results.headline: A Long Way Traveled, With Farther Still to Go

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hermanas

results.summary_short: The ghost of 1970s Argentina haunts 1980s Texas in this perceptive and beautifully acted drama from the Argentine director Julia Solomonoff.

results.headline: Graduate Degree in Grossness
results.display_title: National Lampoon's Van Wilder: The Rise of Taj

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of National Lampoon's Van Wilder: The Rise of Taj

results.summary_short: Britain and India face off in “National Lampoon’s Van Wilder 2: The Rise of Taj,” a strained attempt to transplant the American campus comedy to more uptight shores.

results.headline: Lingering on the Express Line: Bagging Some Humanity Amid Bar-Code Scanners

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 10 Items Or Less

results.summary_short: Brad Silberling’s new movie has nothing to prove, and not all that much to say, but its modesty and good humor make it hard to resist.
